entry.title: [PA] Isolate memory reclaimer into its own experiment
entry.content:
So far it piggybacked on PartitionAllocBackupRefPtr, as its accidental

disabledness was related to BRP enabledness. But now that BRP is

launched, it memory reclaimer deserves its own feature flag, so that

it can be investigated independently.



The only behavior difference under default settings is that memory

reclaimer is started only after FeatureList is initialized. The additional difference, under non-default settings, is that all partitions are now controlled by the feature flag, whereas

PartitionAllocBackupRefPtr controlled only the new main partition.



Note, PartitionAllocBackupRefPtr no longer has "...WithMemoryReclaimer"

modes.



Bug: 1462316, 1462319

Change-Id: Ie8ebff73e335eb35732e7ad747b073bb48b7486e

entry.title: Context menu entry for ac=unrecognized fallback
entry.content:
Introduces the feature flag AutofillFallbackForAutocompleteUnrecognized.

When enabled, an "Addresses and more" entry is added to the context menu

of ac=unrecognized address-Autofill fields. If the entry is selected,

Autofill suggestions are shown, which fill all fields of the triggering

field's section - independently of the autocomplete attribute.



Due to the preparatory work in the prior CLs, this is achieved by simply

triggering suggestions through the renderer using the suggestion trigger

source kManualFallbackForAutocompleteUnrecognized.



The logic added in autofill_context_menu_manager.cc ensures that the

context menu entry is only shown for the relevant fields.



Demo: https://screencast.googleplex.com/cast/NDk2Nzc2ODIxNTUxOTIzMnwwYzRjZmRkYy0wZA



Bug: 1446318

entry.title: [Tab Switcher] Prevent thumbnail capture on interrupted animation
entry.content:
If the animation is interrupted, skipped, or shortened the

finishedShowing() delayed tasks were still run. This could result in

invalidating mLayoutTabs or triggering multiple thumbnail captures.



The previous fix forced mLayoutTabs to be initialized during the

animation. However, a better solution is to just remove the callback

from the handler if another call to show() is made or we start hiding.

This fixes the issue of invalid mLayoutTabs and prevents repeat

thumbnail captures.

This reverts commit 285a3d7b0a83eeb5c0c349e5a97a5840e4752221.



Reason for revert: The spec has been renamed back to Private Network Access https://github.com/WICG/private-network-access/pull/106

> [Local Network Access] Rename content browser clients from private to local

>

> In https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access/issues/91, we decided to

> already been renamed in

> https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access/pull/97. The latest spec:

> https://wicg.github.io/local-network-access/

>

> This CL renames PrivateNetwork to LocalNetwork in content browser

> There are so many places to rename, so during the process, there will

entry.title: [Privacy Sandbox] Implement the loading of attestations list.
entry.content:
This CL implements the following:

1. When component updater signals the file is ready via

`ComponentReady()`, instruct it to invoke the callback, which is

`PrivacySandboxAttestations::LoadAttestations()`.

2. In this callback, it invokes `LoadAttestationsInternal()`

asynchronously on `base::SequencedTaskRunner`.

3. `LoadAttestationsInternal()` validates:

a) The map never exists, this is the first time it's ready or

b) The incoming version is newer than the existing one

Otherwise the file won't be opened and parsed.

4. Then it calls the parser to parse the input. It stores the result

to `PrivacySandboxAttestations` when the parsing is done.

5. Add unit tests.



Changed the async parsing to use `base::SequencedTaskRunner`, instead

of `base::ThreadPool`. The goal is to run parsing tasks in the posting

order.



A `base::SequencedTaskRunner` is created and owned by

`PrivacySandboxAttestations`. It is responsible for opening the file

as a `ifstream` and then parse it.



The final move assignment of the version and the attestations map is

done on UI thread. This is because queries on Privacy Sandbox APIs

attestation status may happen on the UI thread. Having it done on UI

thread can avoid potential race condition.



Moved the checks on whether to open the file and parsing to the start

of `PrivacySandboxAttestations::LoadAttestationsInternal()`. This

avoids opening the file then finds it no need to parse the list. For

example, when the incoming version is older, there is no need to parse

it, we keep the existing map.



In the next CL, a browser test will be added. After this CL is merged,

we will be able to manually verify that the component updater is

able to download the file and then load the attestations file to

the in-memory map via the callback.



Bug: 1448875

Change-Id: I519c25fab3f304b9e6d401558c75a44ce406ed35

entry.title: DTC-BYOD: Add client-side VA flow for DTC
entry.content:
Add support for the VA flow type

VerifiedAccessFlow::DEVICE_TRUST_CONNECTOR in TpmChallengeKeySubtle.

This flow type will be used to attest the signal payload from DTC on

unmanaged devices. The key name needs to be defined by the caller. A

default key name is not supported since it needs to be different for

different usernames. For more context, see

go/remote-attestation-unmanaged-devices-dd.

entry.title: canvas: Skip DispatchFrame for null canvas resource
entry.content:
If the `canvas_resource` is null, DispatchFrame is a no-op, but we still

dereference the null resource to compute needs_vertical_flip which shows

up in clusterfuzz. Skip the entire DispatchFrame section to avoid this.



Bug: 1462273

entry.title: Revert "[Local Network Access] Rename net error from private to local"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 601e0d1490a62fc9c1f4b7debde9e431aa92d7c0.



Reason for revert: The spec has been renamed back to Private Network Access https://github.com/WICG/private-network-access/pull/106



Original change's description:

> [Local Network Access] Rename net error from private to local

>

> In https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access/issues/91, we decided to

> rename Private Network Access to Local Network Access. The spec has

> already been renamed in

> https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access/pull/97. The latest spec:

> https://wicg.github.io/local-network-access/

>

> This CL renames PrivateNetwork to LocalNetwork in net errors.

>

> There are so many places to rename, so during the process, there will

> inevitably be inconsistencies. Hopefully, we shall resolve all of them

> soon.

>

> Bug: 1418287

> Change-Id: Id6338a3efb6ab2e5f31a8488240e611e8a7ffc47

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4334570

entry.content:

Marked flags as launched (per go/finch101#post-launch-clean-up) where

they are enabled-by-default and some have finch configs showing that

they were launched. These flags should be removed and the related

code cleaned up:

- kAutofillEnforceDelaysInStrikeDatabase

- kAutofillFillMerchantPromoCodeFields

- kAutofillRemoveCardExpirationAndTypeTitles

- kAutofillSaveCardInfobarEditSupport

- kAutofillUseEloRegexForBinMatching



Also identified the following flags which appear to be unused

(disabled by default, no finch config turning them on), but not

touched in this CL:

- kAutofillAlwaysReturnCloudTokenizedCard

- kAutofillShowUnmaskedCachedCardInManualFillingView

entry.title: [iOS] Implement UIShutdownNoDismiss for TrustedVaultReauthenticationCoordinator
entry.content:
This patch implement correctly the case to interrupt

TrustedVaultReauthenticationCoordinator for

SigninCoordinatorInterrupt::UIShutdownNoDismiss.



For UIShutdownNoDismiss case, the UI doesn't need to be dismiss, but

sign-in completion block and the interrupt completion block need to be

called in that order and synchronously before the end of

-[SigninCoordinator interruptWithAction:completion:].



Related to crrev.com/c/4665648.

entry.title: Store the COOP restrict crossOriginIsolated bit in policy container.
entry.content:
In https://crrev.com/c/4479858, we introduced a new boolean that

constrains whether an execution context can be considered

crossOriginIsolated. It is computed by the browser, depending on whether

the COOP origin matches the actual origin. This boolean is computed and

sent to the renderer at window creation time, or at commit time for

subframes. It causes breakage such as b/288962508 (Google

only) because SharedArrayBuffer's constructor sometimes needs to be

enabled earlier than CommitNavigation, which causes SharedArrayBuffer to

be undefined even though crossOriginIsolated is true.



This CL instead puts the boolean inside the policy container and lets it

handles inheritance.



Bug: 1385827

Change-Id: I1330c30ad056d9f94ee7b7747eac68ae47b56acc

entry.title: Fix bug when passing dropped events to next presented frames
entry.content:
Before the fix we were checking begin frame id to see if we can pass the

events to the reporter or not, but that is not fully correct since it is

possible that a successfully presented frame after a dropped frame can

have reporter corresponding to begin frame before the dropped frame for

e.g. when a main thread update is taking long.



| R1main |

| R1impl | R2impl | R3impl |



In scenario above if it was main thread scroll i.e. R1impl and R2impl

had scroll events marked with requires_main_thread_update. If R2impl

gets dropped then ideally we would like R1main to receive those inputs

instead of R3impl. But as per current logic it would go to R3impl.



Bug: b/289809665

Change-Id: Ia5dffc3f9cf8bca8bb94d308c40f9fe188d3b46e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4664413

Reviewed-by: Jonathan Ross

Reviewed-by: Stephen Nusko

Commit-Queue: Kartar Singh

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1168635}

entry.title: [LCPP] HTMLPreloadScanner consumes LCP ElementLocator hints
entry.content:
This CL implements the renderer-side read-path for LCP ElementLocator.

After this CL:

- A member `lcp_element_locators` is added to

LCPCriticalPathPredictorNavigationTimeHint to plumb the info from

browser process to the renderer process.

- `WebLocalFrameImpl::SetLCPPHint` forwards the received hint to `LCPCriticalPathPredictor` instance.

- HTMLPreloadScanner is initialized with the element locators

available on LCPP, so that HTMLPreloadScanner can annotate the

matching `PreloadRequests` as `IsPotentiallyLCPElement` for the locators.



since it required non-trivial changes to the test infra.



Test: The test exercises the code is split to a different CL,

Bug: 1419756

entry.title: internals.getInitialResourcePriority return priorities for cached resources
entry.content:
Before this CL, a web_test testing API getInitialResourcePriority

supported querying resource priority for only not yet loaded resources.



This CL extends the API so that it can report priority for already

loaded resources which turned out to be alive.



For the tests relying on the previous behavior, `getInitialResourcePriorityOfNewLoad` is provided.

third_party/blink/web_tests/http/tests/doc-write-intervention/doc-write-sync-third-party-script-block.html

was the only such test.

entry.title: Suggestion labels for manual fallbacks.
entry.content:
When generating suggestion labels, right now, only the triggering

field's type and the types of all ac != unrecognized fields are taken

into consideration. This works for regular Autofill suggestions, since

they don't fill ac=unrecognized fields.



With manual fallbacks, ac=unrecognized fields can be filled. This CL

thus makes suggestion label generation dependent on the

AutofillSuggestionTriggerSource. In particular, when the trigger source

is kManualFallbackForAutocompleteUnrecognized, the types of all fields

in the section are taken into consideration.



This is done by passing the trigger source to label generation along

this path:

BAM::GetAvailableSuggestions() -> BAM::GetProfileSuggestions() ->

AutofillSuggestionGenerator::GetSuggestionsForProfiles().

There, the CL's one-line actual change happens.



This CL also removes some unnecessary parameters along the call path:

- Instead of passing the entire AutofillField to

GetProfileSuggestions() and GetSuggestionsForProfiles(), only the

AutofillType of the field is needed.

- The AutofillField parameter of FieldFiller::

GetPhoneNumberValueForInput() is unused (called from

GetSuggestionsForProfiles()).



Bug: 1446318

Change-Id: Icf413a2b3dd5406e358d2b0e8879985f443677dd

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4659906

Commit-Queue: Florian Leimgruber

Reviewed-by: Dominic Battre

entry.title: [DBSC] Make it easier to test binding keys on Linux and Mac
entry.content:
//crypto currently has an UnexportableKeyProvider support on Windows

only. Since most of the future developers work on Linux and Mac, it will

be helpful to be able to test the feature on these platforms.



To facilite local development, this CL adds a mock software-backed

implementation of an UnexportableKeyProvider behind a feature flag. This

feature flag is expected to never be shipped to end users.



The flag is checked on the UnexportableKeyService level, so only

DBSC-related code will switch to an insecure implementation.

entry.content:
...for signed-in, non-syncing users.

This ensures that when some client asks "is this type preferred", the

answer makes sense: Only types that are actually supported in the

current state will be listed as selected.



Previously, crrev.com/c/4650996 made the analogous change for

GetSelectedTypes().



As a bonus, this lets us remove GetDataTypesToConfigure() (it was

always a bit weird that this existed next to GetPreferredDataTypes()).

entry.title: iwa: Implement command to apply pending updates
entry.content:
This is the second command needed for the IWA update process. This

command applies a pending update of the IWA, by reading information

about the pending update from `IsolationData::PendingUpdateInfo`. After

the command finishes, regardless of whether it succeeds or fails, we

delete the pending update info.

If the command succeeds, then it will update location and version of the

IWA with the data from the pending update info. This is done as part of

`WebAppInstallFinalizer::FinalizeUpdate`.



The whole update flow will look like this:

- The `IsolatedWebAppUpdateManager` discovers and downloads an update

- The update is prepared and stored in the pending update info by the

`IsolatedWebAppPrepareAndStoreUpdateCommand`.

- Then, we wait for the right time to apply the update, such as when the

app is closed or when the browser restarts (not yet implemented).

- Then, we execute the new `IsolatedWebAppApplyUpdateCommand` to apply

the update.



Bug: 1444407

Change-Id: I904d78ec06be2ba1215d402d24f989453e032c9b

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4665437

entry.title: [mac] Always use zero-copy for video capture on mac unless disabled
entry.content:
Before CL[1], mac platforms always used zero-copy(GBM) regardless of

commandline switch.

(a) A zero-copy copy is used even when

--disable-video-capture-use-gpu-memory-buffer is provided.

(b) If a switches are not provided, zero-copy is used.



CL[1] implements zero-copy selection based on command-line switches.



After CL[1], Chorme's behavior is changed when launched without any

GBM-related switch. Previously, Chorme used zero-copy (GBM), but now

since no explicit instruction to use GMB is provided, it doesn't use

zero-copy. Refer discussion on [2] for more information.



The Mac and iOS share this implementation, but iOS does not yet

support zero-copy(GBM), so switches are required to select software

path (shared memory) implementation.



In this CL, for mac platform, zero-copy(GBM) is always used unless the

user explicitly asks to disable it.



[1] https://crrev.com/c/4551060

[2] https://crrev.com/c/4551060/3/media/capture/capture_switches.cc



Bug: 1458391

Change-Id: Ia35090b9306fc3c185d15da5b6c2c5e5a534c8a7

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4653786

entry.title: PA: Add address space diagram
entry.content:
This CL trivially adds a model of how address space (specifically pools

in 64-bit environments) is divvied up. Access is mediated by the

singular `AddressPoolManager` class. Pools are large contiguous runs of

address space, but the carve-outs given to each root (to each partition)

in the form of super pages may not be so.

entry.title: Count UseCounter regardless of the feature flag
entry.content:
The previous CL [1] introduced a UseCounter for "port overflow", but

it counts only when the feature flag is enabled. The flag is disabled

by default. The UseCounter currently remains at zero [2].



This CL fixes this behavior so it counts regardless of the feature

flag.

[2] https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/4503

entry.title: [loading] Fix DelegatingBytesConsumer::GetError
entry.content:
If |GetPublicState| returns |kErrored| then calling |GetError| should

be valid.

In the case of |ResponseBodyLoader::DelegatingBytesConsumer| this was

not the case because |GetPublicState| would return |kErrored| if loading

was aborted, but |GetError| would relay to the underlying

|BytesConsumer| which might not be in an errored state and thus might

not allow to call |GetError|.



R=yoavweiss@chromium.org



Bug: chromium:1449546

Change-Id: I0ab3d879827dace64b9b1c9c2fde5357e3072f5a

entry.title: [Lacros] Remove kWebAppsCrosapi flag.
entry.content:
Web apps in Lacros is depend on the LacrosPrimary status for a long

time, and the Lacros flags and kWebAppsCrosapi flags are disabled

by default, therefore we can safely remove the development purposed

flag and use the Lacros flags instead. This CL should have no

functional change.



In the tests, we replace the kWebAppsCrosapi flag to actually enabling

the kLacrosSupport, kLacrosPrimary, and kLacrosOnly flags, and add a

check to verify that the Lacros is actually primary browser, because a

logged-in user is needed to actually have Lacros enabled.



BUG=1440448

existing code to avoid duplicate codes)

vairant

- Update tests so that it work with Lacros test support (mainly

changing certain test to expect async response)



The Lacros implementation should still behind the kAppStoreBilling flag,

and there should be no functional change in the original ash

implementation.

entry.title: dlp: Support unzip of managed archives
entry.content:
Currently unzipped files are not tracked by the DLP daemon.

With this CL, we define the source URL of unzipped files to be the

source URL of the archive containing them. This source URL is sent to

the DLP daemon as soon as the extraction is completed.

This is done within a DlpExtractIOTaskObserver.

entry.title: Revert "Fix URL parser to allow "%00" as a valid URL path"
entry.content:
This reverts commit ddebb144aa642f40f8df600687b3611396756d32.



Reason for revert: Culprit of test failures of:

external/wpt/url/url-setters.any.html?exclude=(file|javascript|mailto)

external/wpt/url/url-setters.any.worker.html?exclude=(file|javascript|mailto)

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/mac13-arm64-rel-tests/2027/overview

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/mac11-arm64-rel-tests/21749/overview

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/WebKit%20Win10/118794/overview



Original change's description:

> Fix URL parser to allow "%00" as a valid URL path

>

> This CL is part of the URL interop 2023 effort.

>

> The problem:

>

> Chrome currently considers a URL invalid if the URL's path part

> contains "%00" (or null), which is not compliant with the URL Standard

> [1]. For example, the following test fails in Chrome because new

> URL(..) throws an Invalid URL exception.

>

> assertEquals(new URL("http://example.com/%00").pathname, "/%00");

>

> According to the URL Standard, any character or byte sequence in URL

> path should not make the URL invalid.

>

> Interoperability:

>

> - Chrome is the only non-compliant browser, while Firefox and Safari

> are compliant.

> - I have also tested URL APIs in non-browser environments and

> libraries, such as Deno's `URL` implementation [2] and Rust's `url`

> crate [3], both of which accept "%00" as a valid URL.

>

> History:

>

> This behavior seems to be a result of past decisions. The comment in

> `url_canon_path.cc` states:

>

> > // This table was used to be designed to match exactly what IE did

> > // with the characters.

>

> This CL updates the table so that "%00" in URL's path is no longer

> considered invalid. Further updates to the table will be addressed as

> another issue (https://crbug.com/1252531).

>

> Note that this CL only affects the URL's path. In other parts of URL,

> "%00" may still be considered invalid. For example,

>

> new URL("http://example%00.com/")

>

> throws an exception because "%00" is not a valid host codepoint.

>

> Tests:

>

> Updating this behavior requires modifying existing web tests and unit

> tests that rely on Chrome's non-compliant behavior.

>

> Some usages of "%00" in unit tests can be replaced with any invalid

> URL because their purpose is to represent an invalid URL, such as

> "https://example[invalid].com/".

>

> Additionally, some tests can be removed since a URL is never invalid

> due to its path part after this CL.

>

> As for WPT tests, all rebaseline are generated using `git cl

> rebaseline`, and no manual updates were made to expectation files.

> Most rebaselines are understandable, and many WPT tests are now

> passing.

>

> The impacts:

>

> A URL path can now include "%00". This may raise concerns.

>

> For websites, how to handle "%00" in the URL's path is up-to each

> website. Since they can receive such a URL from other clients than

> Chrome, this is not a new issue for most websites.

>

> In term of implementation, web-exported URL APIs, GURL, and KURL share

> the same URL parser and canonicalization backend. Another concern is

> likely related to Chromium's internal code, which many assume that a

> valid URL never contains "%00" in its path.

>

> After this CL, that assumption is no longer true. If necessary,

> Chromium's internal code needs to handle NULL in some way when

> percent-decoding the URL's path for specific reasons. For example,

> this CL updates `FileURLToFilePath` function defined in

> `filename_util.cc` so that NULL is handled in this layer.

>

> It is challenging to assess every code path like this since URLs are

> widely used, and there may be "Unknown Unknowns". Any ideas on how to

> confidently land this CL without causing any breakages are welcome. If

> you encounter a null pointer dereference crash and find this CL in the

> regression range, this CL might be a culprit.

>

> - [1] https://url.spec.whatwg.org/

> - [2] https://deno.land/api@v1.34.3?s=URL

> - [3] https://docs.rs/url/latest/url/

>

> Bug: 1400251

> Change-Id: Ic2c774835e68f835ff5c9c7e881b6ad6847d17b1

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4596360

> Reviewed-by: Orin Jaworski

> Commit-Queue: Hayato Ito

> Reviewed-by: Daniel Cheng

> Reviewed-by: Maxim Kolosovskiy

This unittest is carrying a lot of historical baggage. This CL strips it

entry.title: [GPU] Remove Texture::has_images_
entry.content:
The Texture::has_images_ boolean is never set to true following

the elimination of GLImage:



* It is initialized to false

* Texture::UpdateHasImages() sets a `has_images` local variable to false

and early-outs if `has_images == has_images_` (which it always will)



This CL removes Texture::has_images_ and ripple-effect dead code.



Note: The removal of

GLES2DecoderImpl::NeedsCopyTextureImageWorkaround() is doubly-safe as

that function returns false if the

`use_intermediary_for_copy_texture_image` isn't set, and that

workaround is set only on OS X (which no longer uses the validating

decoder).



Bug: 1310018

Change-Id: I4e23b8053a5b7445f4d3325055ef5f1304c8dd5e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4672657

Commit-Queue: Colin Blundell

entry.title: [//media] Reallow external sampling to be passed to ReadbackTexturePlane
entry.content:
I recently landed a CL to CHECK that VideoFrames requiring external

sampling are not passed to ReadbackTexturePlaneToMemorySyncOOP().

However, as vasilyt@ subsequently pointed out, this was based on a

flawed understanding of how this code works. This code is set up to

handle VideoFrames requiring external sampling by copying them as a

single opaque texture. It does so by setting the readback format to

RGB [1] and then iterating over the number of planes of the readback

format (not of the source VideoFrame) [2].



Since this codepath is intentionally supported, it is presumably

entered :). This CL reverts the CHECK that I added.



[1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main:media/base/video_util.cc;l=90-91;drc=9d4eb7ed25296abba8fd525a6bdd0fdbf4bcdd9f

[2] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main:media/base/video_util.cc;l=782-783;drc=9d4eb7ed25296abba8fd525a6bdd0fdbf4bcdd9f;bpv=1;bpt=1



Bug: 1457134, 1459252

Change-Id: Ib4aa59614eb92a9f43d75dc3941b70a5ded4e7b3

#0 0x5611af2d5eee in RemoveObserverFromChildren ./../../ash/wm/screen_pinning_controller.cc:50:28

#1 0x5611af2d5eee in ash::ScreenPinningController::ResetWindowPinningState() ./../../ash/wm/screen_pinning_controller.cc:288:3

#2 0x5611af2d4d84 in ash::ScreenPinningController::SetPinnedWindow(aura::Window*) ./../../ash/wm/screen_pinning_controller.cc:225:5

#3 0x5611af3ed98b in ash::DefaultState::EnterToNextState(ash::WindowState*, chromeos::WindowStateType,



Original change's description:

> Clean up proper container in ScreenPinningController

>

> The parent container of a pinned window is set up for pinned mode

> in SetPinnedWindow() and cleaned up in ResetWindowPinningState().

>

> These functions need to target the same container but depending

> on the timing of ResetWindowPinningState() being called, the

> pinned window may have already moved to another container at the

> point ResetWindowPinningState() is called and could unexpectedly

> clean up the incorrect container.

>

> With this CL, the container is tracked in ScreenPinningController

> so we can ensure to clean up the proper container.

>

> Bug: b/287903215

> Test: WM CTS dosen't crash.

entry.title: Fix URL parser to allow "%00" as a valid URL path
entry.content:
This CL is part of the URL interop 2023 effort.



The problem:



Chrome currently considers a URL invalid if the URL's path part

contains "%00" (or null), which is not compliant with the URL Standard

[1]. For example, the following test fails in Chrome because new

URL(..) throws an Invalid URL exception.



assertEquals(new URL("http://example.com/%00").pathname, "/%00");



According to the URL Standard, any character or byte sequence in URL

path should not make the URL invalid.



Interoperability:



- Chrome is the only non-compliant browser, while Firefox and Safari

are compliant.

- I have also tested URL APIs in non-browser environments and

libraries, such as Deno's `URL` implementation [2] and Rust's `url`

crate [3], both of which accept "%00" as a valid URL.



History:



This behavior seems to be a result of past decisions. The comment in

`url_canon_path.cc` states:



> // This table was used to be designed to match exactly what IE did

> // with the characters.



This CL updates the table so that "%00" in URL's path is no longer

considered invalid. Further updates to the table will be addressed as

another issue (https://crbug.com/1252531).



Note that this CL only affects the URL's path. In other parts of URL,

"%00" may still be considered invalid. For example,



new URL("http://example%00.com/")



throws an exception because "%00" is not a valid host codepoint.



Tests:



Updating this behavior requires modifying existing web tests and unit

tests that rely on Chrome's non-compliant behavior.



Some usages of "%00" in unit tests can be replaced with any invalid

URL because their purpose is to represent an invalid URL, such as

"https://example[invalid].com/".



Additionally, some tests can be removed since a URL is never invalid

due to its path part after this CL.



As for WPT tests, all rebaseline are generated using `git cl

rebaseline`, and no manual updates were made to expectation files.

Most rebaselines are understandable, and many WPT tests are now

passing.



The impacts:



A URL path can now include "%00". This may raise concerns.



For websites, how to handle "%00" in the URL's path is up-to each

website. Since they can receive such a URL from other clients than

Chrome, this is not a new issue for most websites.



In term of implementation, web-exported URL APIs, GURL, and KURL share

the same URL parser and canonicalization backend. Another concern is

likely related to Chromium's internal code, which many assume that a

valid URL never contains "%00" in its path.



After this CL, that assumption is no longer true. If necessary,

Chromium's internal code needs to handle NULL in some way when

percent-decoding the URL's path for specific reasons. For example,

this CL updates `FileURLToFilePath` function defined in

`filename_util.cc` so that NULL is handled in this layer.



It is challenging to assess every code path like this since URLs are

widely used, and there may be "Unknown Unknowns". Any ideas on how to

confidently land this CL without causing any breakages are welcome. If

you encounter a null pointer dereference crash and find this CL in the

regression range, this CL might be a culprit.



- [1] https://url.spec.whatwg.org/

- [2] https://deno.land/api@v1.34.3?s=URL

- [3] https://docs.rs/url/latest/url/



Bug: 1400251

Change-Id: Ic2c774835e68f835ff5c9c7e881b6ad6847d17b1

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4596360

entry.title: jellyroll shadow [part 1]: add shadow details key
entry.content:
Design doc: go/jellyroll-shadow



Currently, a shadow's appearance is only determined by the shadow

elevation, rounded corner radius, and shadow style (shadow style

determines how the blur radius is calculated). Since we are going

to apply dynamic colors to the shadow, the key and ambient shadow

colors should also be considered, when specifying a shadow.



This cl adds a new ShadowDetailsKey that contains the rounded corner

radius and shadow values. This key includes all the information needed

to determine the appearance of the shadow and will be used as the key

for shadow details cache.



The following cls will apply dynamic colors to the shadow based on

this change.



Test: ShadowUtilTest.ShadowDetailsKey

Bug: b:252359187

entry.title: Add feature flag for Zstd Content-Encoding
entry.content:
This CL introduces a net feature: ZstdContentEncoding

When this feature is enabled, the browser will support zstd

content-encoding and send the "zstd" token in the Accept-Encoding

header in Chromium and WebView. The feature is disabled by default.
